channel.title: Y iz jagex bytecoding
channel.description:
So like, I was makin myself a loader-loader out of boredom, and I come across a "unpackclass.jar" being downloaded and loaded in the client: [code] byte abyte1[] = a("unpackclass.jar?crc=-549807395", -3314, new File(d.f, "game_unpacker.dat"), 17836, s);[/code] nso, I look in dis set of classes and find what seems to be a bytecode class parser/reconstructor/assembler? .. why? http://why.did.you.rm-rf.us/~regecks/unpackclass.java for the lazy ones .. ? Does this have something to do with the silly pack200 the client comes in now? FX FK KF KFK FK FX FX FX myb dey like screw up the classformat and then fix it on the other side of the launcher? myb
aaaanywwwwwwwayyyy the implication is that not going through the loader will potentially make bad things happen, n editing the classes will also potentially make things happen, plz helpz

item.title: Y iz jagex bytecoding
item.dc:creator: @semaphore semaphore
item.description:
@semaphore wrote:

Method counting would only work if you are injecting code ignorantly. One of the things I do every time I decide the only way to get around some issue is through injection, is figure out the ways my injection can be detected. The most basic defense you have is closely monitoring the ClassLoader. Know what is and is not loaded. Look for signatures in the bytecode. Know how often some things are supposed to happen and if they happen more or less than you expect, raise a flag.

Keep in mind, if they want to catch you, they will. There is very little you can do to be prepared for every possible change they could make. So stay on your toes.

Read full topic

item.title: Y iz jagex bytecoding
item.dc:creator: @Taios Taios
item.description:
@Taios wrote:

Krichevskoy:

Simple method counting would catch ARGA certainly, and probably every other bot in existence right now.

Would catch ARGA yes. I know of others though implementing ways to prevent such methods of detection.

Read full topic

item.title: Y iz jagex bytecoding
item.dc:creator: @semaphore semaphore
item.description:
@semaphore wrote:

Is it far too much to ask of ‘community members’ to refrain from idiot speak?

If you look closely, unpackclass is only needed if you do not have Pack200. Pack200 is a sun approved/developed/sanctioned jar packer. It is quite efficient (compared to what you or I could do). If you are using any jre/jdk below 1.5, you will likely not have Pack200 as it first started shipping with 1.5+. unpackclass is basically their implementation of pack200 for jdk 1.4.2.

byte was on the right track. There will be a problem loading that game code from their cache because they try to load Pack200 first. That will fail, and invoke the downloading and execution of their version. Again, this will only happen on jdk/jre 1.4.2. If you use 1.5+ you’ll avoid any usage of their shared unpacker.

Read full topic

item.title: Y iz jagex bytecoding
item.dc:creator: @byte byte
item.description:
@byte wrote:

If you examine my program’s dump you will see that this bytecode utility is never loaded by either class loader (the browser’s or the game’s). Take a look at loader.java and you will notice, as I mentioned earlier, unpackclass is only loaded iff their’s a problem reading the game code from the cache or downloading that same file.

Read full topic

item.title: Y iz jagex bytecoding
item.dc:creator: @regecks1 regecks`
item.description:
@regecks1 wrote:

The class object is definitely created:

class1 = a1.loadClass("unpackclass");[br][size=1]Posted on: March 12, 2007, 06:33:41 PM[/size][hr]Ok I just checked properly and the object is initialized:

a1.b = (unpack)class1.getConstructor(new Class[] { Class.forName("[B"), Boolean.TYPE }).newInstance(new Object[] { throwable, Boolean.TRUE });

public unpackclass(byte abyte0[], boolean flag) throws IOException {Nevermind the mismatches in the object types, that’s just jad mismatching load indexes due to obfuscation

item.title: Y iz jagex bytecoding
item.dc:creator: @byte byte
item.description:
@byte wrote:

It’s strange that these classes are never run, much less loaded. Take a look at the output a small app I just whipped up:

Loading class loader with class loader: sun.plugin.security.PluginClassLoader@182bcde.
Loading class b with class loader: sun.plugin.security.PluginClassLoader@182bcde.
Loading class unpack with class loader: sun.plugin.security.PluginClassLoader@182bcde.
Loading class c with class loader: sun.plugin.security.PluginClassLoader@182bcde.
Loading class a with class loader: sun.plugin.security.PluginClassLoader@182bcde.
Loading class we with class loader: sun.plugin.security.PluginClassLoader@182bcde.
Loading class ub with class loader: sun.plugin.security.PluginClassLoader@182bcde.
Loading class mc with class loader: sun.plugin.security.PluginClassLoader@182bcde.
Loading class lb with class loader: sun.plugin.security.PluginClassLoader@182bcde.
Loading class client with class loader: a@b05acd.
Loading class fc with class loader: a@b05acd.
Loading class ja with class loader: a@b05acd.
Loading class k with class loader: a@b05acd.
Loading class sd with class loader: a@b05acd.
Loading class ge with class loader: a@b05acd.
Loading class lc with class loader: a@b05acd.
Loading class cb with class loader: a@b05acd.
Loading class wc with class loader: a@b05acd.
Loading class jf with class loader: a@b05acd.
Loading class qd with class loader: a@b05acd.
Loading class j with class loader: a@b05acd.
Loading class pc with class loader: a@b05acd.
Loading class ka with class loader: a@b05acd.
Loading class ve with class loader: a@b05acd.
Loading class hb with class loader: a@b05acd.
Loading class na with class loader: a@b05acd.
Loading class mb with class loader: a@b05acd.
Loading class af with class loader: a@b05acd.
Loading class vd with class loader: a@b05acd.
Loading class hf with class loader: a@b05acd.
Loading class db with class loader: a@b05acd.
Loading class s with class loader: a@b05acd.
Loading class sa with class loader: a@b05acd.
Loading class u with class loader: a@b05acd.
Loading class ie with class loader: a@b05acd.
Loading class nd with class loader: a@b05acd.
Loading class ca with class loader: a@b05acd.
Loading class rc with class loader: a@b05acd.
Loading class kc with class loader: a@b05acd.
Loading class kf with class loader: a@b05acd.
...

These are the classes loaded during a normal course of events when launching the game from their website. IIRC, and I believe I do, this bytecode utility is only loaded + run if their is a problem reading/downloading the game code in the cache directory.

Read full topic
